mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Fbusiness%20functions%2Fmckinsey%20digital%2Four%20insights%2Fhow%20mexico%20can%20become%20latin%20americas%20digital%20government%20powerhouse%2Fhow-mexico-can-become-latin-americas-digital-government-powerhouse.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" data-layer-report-name="how-mexico-can-become-latin-americas-digital-government-powerhouse>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (PDF-2 MB)</span></a></div></div></div></div> <p><strong>For decades, Mexican citizens</strong> who wanted to get a copy of their birth certificates underwent a long, tedious, and uncertain process. They needed to retrieve their parents’ birth certificates, get a document signed by a representative of the Mexican Ministry of Health, and visit a local office of the Civil Registry. When the certificate finally arrived, anywhere between two weeks and two months later, there were sometimes errors in the name, date of birth, and even gender.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor-signup mck-o-sm-left-span mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-signup"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-7 DisruptorSignUp_mck-c-disruptor-signup__heading__JR4i0"><div>Stay current on your favorite topics</div></h2></div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--align-left"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/user-registration/register-mvc" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Subscribe</span></a></div></div>
<p>Today, however, Mexicans can get a secure, certified, and error-free copy of their birth certificate
within minutes by logging onto gob.mx, a one-stop portal that consolidates 34,000 databases from 250 government institutions and 5,400 public services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="037ec149-717b-4cd9-900d-8310d8949789"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="037ec149-717b-4cd9-900d-8310d8949789" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Estrategia Digital Nacional: Ventanilla Única Nacional, gob.mx.</span></span></span></a></span> The site, launched in 2014, is the centerpiece of Mexico’s drive to digitize the operations of its federal government—part of a wave of such efforts <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-opportunity-in-government-productivity">to improve government productivity</a> taking place across the globe.</p>
<p>Still in the early stages of its digitization journey, Mexico ranks 55th in McKinsey’s analysis of the digital maturity of 151 countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="76e6b2d2-0ec1-4d51-9b59-f929a8baa81c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="76e6b2d2-0ec1-4d51-9b59-f929a8baa81c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">To assess the digital maturity of 151 countries, we used 26 publicly available indicators (such as those from the International Telecommunication Union, United Nations, and World Bank) to analyze four key dimensions of a government’s digital strategy: digital foundations, government, economy, and society.</span></span></span></a></span> When compared with countries with similar per capita GDPs, this is a laudable standing. But Mexico has yet to achieve the kind of world-class digital transformation that fuels productivity and economic growth; as of right now, the country is about halfway there. To move forward, the Mexican government’s ambitions should be more closely aligned with those of <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/digitizing-the-state-five-tasks-for-national-governments">higher-performing countries</a> like Estonia and Malaysia—nations with income levels close to that of Mexico but that “punch above their weight” in regard to digital maturity (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/how%20mexico%20can%20become%20latin%20americas%20digital%20government%20powerhouse/svgz-how-mexico-digital-gov-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Mexico shows a good performance when compared with other countries with similar GDPs." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/how%20mexico%20can%20become%20latin%20americas%20digital%20government%20powerhouse/svgz-how-mexico-digital-gov-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>We estimate that were Mexico to attain a “good” or “very good” digital-maturity rating, it would boost
the country’s GDP by 7 to 15 percent (or $115 billion to $240 billion) by 2025. The growth would come from greater productivity and employment in existing sectors, the creation of new digital (or digitally powered) businesses, the expansion of the information-and-communication-technology (ICT) sector, and a successful labor-force transition to these new digital industries (Exhibit 2).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="edb2e291-3c06-4fcb-9bb5-7b477bae16a0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="edb2e291-3c06-4fcb-9bb5-7b477bae16a0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">To measure the economic value of boosting digital adoption in a country, we estimated the potential impact that achieving an average level of digitization (as measured by the penetration of traditional information and communication technology) would have on the productivity growth of aspirational countries. We also estimated the potential productivity and employment impact of the successful adoption of process-automation technologies, the Internet of Things, and online platforms for better matching of talent supply with job demand.</span></span></span></a></span> As the second-largest economy in Latin America, Mexico also has a unique opportunity to set the standards for what a digitally enabled government looks like in the region.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/how%20mexico%20can%20become%20latin%20americas%20digital%20government%20powerhouse/svgz-how-mexico-digital-gov-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Getting to a higher level of digitization could boost Mexico’s GDP by up to 15 percent." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/how%20mexico%20can%20become%20latin%20americas%20digital%20government%20powerhouse/svgz-how-mexico-digital-gov-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Mexico’s digital underspending</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>In addition to underspending on information and communication technology (ICT), Mexico is spending less on its digital-government unit as compared with digital leaders around the globe. This unit gets 0.003 percent of the total budget, while Canada’s digital unit, for example, receives around 0.012 percent (about 15 times more in terms of total expenditure) and Estonia’s gets 0.105 percent (about one-and-a-half times more in absolute terms, despite having an economy that is 45 times smaller).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b1396eaf-4ea2-4f5c-bd2d-b8a84483307e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b1396eaf-4ea2-4f5c-bd2d-b8a84483307e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Digital Government in Chile: Strengthening the Institutional and Governance Framework</em>, Paris, France: OECD Publishing, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> However, the responsibility for investment does not rest solely with the government. Mexico’s ICT private sector spends 2.0 percent of GDP, versus the 4.7 percent that is the average for our benchmark countries.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Implementing these kind of changes is no small task (see sidebar, “Mexico’s digital underspending”). First, Mexico needs to invest significant additional resources in ICTs, since its government spending lags behind in relation to the weighted average for our benchmark countries: 1.5 percent of the federal budget goes toward ICT versus the 3.9 percent weighted average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0005a23b-c83f-42fd-bd92-e02c12e7042c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0005a23b-c83f-42fd-bd92-e02c12e7042c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Forecast: Enterprise IT spending by vertical industry market, worldwide, 2015–2021</em>, 2017 edition, Gartner, gartner.com; World Economic Outlook, GDP data, International Monetary Fund, April 2018, imf.org; World Bank public-spending data; <em>Digital Government in Chile: Strengthening the Institutional and Governance Framework</em>, Paris, France: OECD Publishing, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> To get up to speed, we estimate that public and private spending on ICT in Mexico would need to increase by at least 5 percent.</p>
<h2>How Mexico stacks up</h2>
<p>In this article, we look at how Mexico is faring along the four critical dimensions used to define digital maturity (government, foundations, economy, and society) (Exhibit 3) and outline the next steps the government could consider taking to become a leader in the digital future.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/how%20mexico%20can%20become%20latin%20americas%20digital%20government%20powerhouse/svgz-how-mexico-digital-gov-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Our comparison in each of the four critical dimensions shows a below-median performance in Mexico in digital foundations and digital economy." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/how%20mexico%20can%20become%20latin%20americas%20digital%20government%20powerhouse/svgz-how-mexico-digital-gov-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Digital foundations</h3>
<p>For citizens to participate in the services of a digital state, they must first have access to the internet, mobile networks, and other secure data infrastructure. But in 2016, Mexico had just 13 fixed-line broadband subscriptions for every 100 inhabitants, ranking it last among both Latin American and Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) peers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3692aa09-9cc4-4814-855b-ad2b8093a96a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3692aa09-9cc4-4814-855b-ad2b8093a96a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Fixed-broadband subscriptions,” ITU, itu.int.</span></span></span></a></span> The rate of subscription to mobile broadband is higher, at 61 percent,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="99f40313-da55-4247-969e-34e1ab759dfa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="99f40313-da55-4247-969e-34e1ab759dfa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">OECD Data Database, indicator: wireless mobile broadband subscriptions, OECD, September 23, 2018, data.oecd.org.</span></span></span></a></span> but this still leaves a sizable portion of the population unconnected and thus spending additional time and money getting to physical centers to access government services. Because of this, Mexico ranks 93rd (again, last among all OECD countries) in our digital-foundations dimension.</p>
<h3>Digital government</h3>
<p>Mexico has made notable progress in its efforts to offer web and mobile access to public services (for those with such access) and to make government more efficient by automating internal processes. In addition to the gob.mx portal, the country has created the role of national digital strategy coordinator within the president’s office and has established a national digital strategy. This has resulted in successful initiatives to make government data available to anyone and has made Mexico the leading Latin American country on the Open Data Barometer world ranking.</p>
<p>The country, however, receives low scores from its citizens on their overall satisfaction with the convenience and accessibility of government services. In a recent survey, Mexico had the worst-rated citizen experience (4.4 out of 10) of the group of countries surveyed (Canada, France, Germany, Mexico, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and the largest perception gap between what people experience in the private sector versus the public sector.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1eebdc3c-9e87-43ce-8377-eb2754146de7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1eebdc3c-9e87-43ce-8377-eb2754146de7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Public Sector Customer Experience Survey. In early 2018, McKinsey surveyed more than 20,000 citizens in six countries (Canada, France, Germany, Mexico, the United Kingdom, and the United States) to find out about their experience as users of public services.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In our digital-government subanalysis, Mexico comes in at 39th (out of 151 countries), similar to Chile, Ireland, and Israel.</p>
<h3>Digital economy</h3>
<p>Mexico’s shaky digital foundations hurt its ability to have mature digital ICT industries. In addition to diminished access to high-speed internet, the reliability of postal services is low, and fewer than
40 percent of Mexicans over the age of 15 have a bank account.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ffbb5b97-33b3-4917-8b5a-64d3607e3bc2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ffbb5b97-33b3-4917-8b5a-64d3607e3bc2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Global Findex Database 2017, World Bank Group, globalfindex.worldbank.org.</span></span></span></a></span> As a result, the country is estimated to have poor potential for developing a robust e-commerce sector, which requires efficient delivery of products and digital forms of payment.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b04956c0-fcf6-4820-a897-0c4cc8ad2ce9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b04956c0-fcf6-4820-a897-0c4cc8ad2ce9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>UNCTAD B2C e-commerce index 2017</em>, United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, October 2017, unctad .org; World Development Indicators Database, World Bank Group, September 2018, databank.worldbank.org; <em>Postal development report 2018: Benchmarking a critical infrastructure for sustainable development</em>, Universal Postal Union, April 2018, upu.int.</span></span></span></a></span> Moreover, less than 1 percent of Mexico’s exported goods and services relate to ICT. McKinsey’s digital-economy subindex places Mexico in 92nd place.</p>
<h3>Digital society</h3>
<p>Digitization can improve the quality of life for citizens by fostering greater civic participation, providing access to information, and offering new tools for health and education. In recent years, Mexico has accelerated its digital-society efforts and ranks 34th on McKinsey’s index. On gob.mx/participa, for instance, citizens participate in public polls and discuss government policies on forums and blogs. At datos.gob.mx/retos, which provides access to Retos Públicos (retos is Spanish for challenges), software entrepreneurs can present solutions to complex public-policy problems, such as the creation of earthquake alerts through push notifications on mobile phones.</p>
<h2>Unlocking the opportunity</h2>
<p>To attain the meaningful economic and societal benefits that come from having a digital government, there are three basic initiatives Mexican government leaders could consider putting on top of their priority lists.</p>
<h3>Defining a digital vision and strategy, then linking them to policy priorities</h3>
<p>Any successful digital transformation—whether in the private or public sector—depends on having a clear vision and defined goals, and then setting priorities. For governments, this means intimately linking digital to public-policy objectives and viewing it as a lever for achieving them. In India, for example, the government framed its goal of transforming the country into a digitally empowered society and knowledge economy in this way: “digital infrastructure as a utility to every citizen.” The UK government talks about developing a world-leading digital economy that works for everyone. To establish a clear link between its digital vision and public value, Mexico’s incoming administration may want to consider revisiting the country’s 2013 National Digital Strategy and aligning it with Mexico’s current and future needs, as well as with the new government’s priorities.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/how-we-help-clients">Digital McKinsey</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<p>This digital vision should be accompanied by a clear set of milestones and metrics that monitor its implementation and impact closely. To ensure success, initiatives that don’t yield the expected results should be rigorously evaluated and adjusted or deprioritized in relation to resources. Such a “test and learn” practice is not native to the public sector and will require the use of different budgeting practices, such as top-down budgets that allow a certain amount of flexibility.</p>
<h3>Setting up the correct delivery mechanism</h3>
<p>Digital transformations require ways of working that are very different from how governments normally operate. Instead of remaking products, processes, and policies according to what benefits each agency, governments running successful transformations typically orient their efforts around what citizens desire and expect. This requires unprecedented, and at times uncomfortable, levels of coordination among previously siloed entities, such as different government agencies, levels of government, and private-sector stakeholders.</p>
<p>To accelerate and streamline this transformation, Mexico could double down on its efforts to centralize digital initiatives across government agencies by providing shared platforms and services so that individual units do not need to “reinvent the wheel” and can focus on actual service delivery. Initially, this could involve coordination through a high-level council that meets regularly. Such a council would oversee digital transformation across the government, including deciding a rollout schedule of initiatives and monitoring their progress with a publicly scrutinized set of periodic key performance indicators. It would also identify obstacles and give support to the different government agencies that can address them. If issues cannot be resolved at this level, the council should have the capacity to escalate them.</p>
<p>Ideally, this central group would have a direct role in designing interoperability and data-architecture standards and would perform ongoing reviews of the digital solutions being implemented by different government agencies. It would also ensure there is a consistent user experience (front end) and compatibility with the data and systems of other agencies (back end). Likewise, the group could play a limited role in implementing pilots or new strategic initiatives, either through its own “digital factory”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0ce5a7cc-29d9-4745-9e58-d7e8e49eb315"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0ce5a7cc-29d9-4745-9e58-d7e8e49eb315" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">An in-house digital-development group with its own engineers, designers, and other workers that develops and launches digital solutions. An example is the US Digital Service, a White House unit with more than 200 software engineers, user-experience designers, and product managers who work with federal agencies to launch digital-lighthouse projects. See Matthias Daub, Axel Domeyer, Julia Klier, and Martin Lundqvist, “<a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/digitizing-the-state-five-tasks-for-national-governments">Digitizing the state: Five tasks for national governments</a>,” November 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> or by managing external vendors.</p>
<p>Eventually, and in a more advanced scenario, the government could form a separate digital delivery unit. The government of Singapore, for example, established the Government Technology Agency (GovTech) as an implementing agency for the Smart Nation and Digital Government Office, both part of the Smart Nation and Digital Government Group under the Prime Minister’s Office.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d114996b-e394-4f20-b3ad-34ec74dfab71"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d114996b-e394-4f20-b3ad-34ec74dfab71" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">GovTech Singapore, tech.gov.sg.</span></span></span></a></span> The unit usually has a strong sponsor. As in Singapore, it may report to the president or prime minister, or the president or prime minister serves as the chair of periodic progress-review meetings.</p>
<h2>Building digital foundations</h2>
<p>Because the gaps in Mexico’s digital foundations have ramifications for each of the three other dimensions, we suggest that addressing five essential building blocks could shore up the country’s infrastructure.</p>
<h3>Boosting digital accessibility</h3>
<p>To increase internet access across Mexico, both national and state-level governments could provide private companies with specific incentives for investing in broadband networks in marginalized communities, such as Chiapas and Oaxaca.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bb2e61e1-3e40-443e-a257-0dd292f1ba05"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bb2e61e1-3e40-443e-a257-0dd292f1ba05" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">BIT Database, Instituto Federal de Telecomunicaciones, September 2018, bit.ift.org.mx.</span></span></span></a></span> In India, for example, the central government helped develop the National Optical Fibre Network (BharatNet) through tax incentives to private providers that make investments in infrastructure. This effort successfully brought broadband services to approximately 115,000 villages, aiming to deliver broadband connectivity to 250,000 villages overall.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6038192a-dd55-49eb-b1c5-85e6618b5a48"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6038192a-dd55-49eb-b1c5-85e6618b5a48" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bharat Broadband Network, bbnl.nic.in.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>In recent years, Mexico has made significant strides to boost the number of college graduates with degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.</p></blockquote></div>
<h3>Nurturing the right kind of talent</h3>
<p>By 2030, automation technologies are expected to displace nine million workers in Mexico,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="623529bd-9193-48e6-88ec-bbd2ee2ba0d1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="623529bd-9193-48e6-88ec-bbd2ee2ba0d1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For the full McKinsey Global Institute report, see “<a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/jobs-lost-jobs-gained-what-the-future-of-work-will-mean-for-jobs-skills-and-wages">Jobs lost, jobs gained: What the future of work will mean for jobs, skills, and wages</a>,” November 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> with the eventual replacement jobs requiring entirely different skills and competencies—most of which the current Mexican educational system is not fully prepared to address. In recent years, Mexico has made significant strides to boost the number of college graduates with degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). In 2016, 25 percent of graduates were from STEM disciplines, which is equal to the OECD average. But overall, Mexico’s education system still lags behind. According to a World Economic Forum survey, the quality of Mexico’s mathematics and science education ranks 126th out of 139 countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c32273b2-6ecf-435b-8b95-44d741065135"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c32273b2-6ecf-435b-8b95-44d741065135" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The Global Information Technology Report 2016</em>, World Economic Forum, July 2016, weforum.org.</span></span></span></a></span> And only 17 percent of Mexicans graduate from college (as compared with the OECD average of 37 percent), making the overall talent pool small.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e6420bdb-b389-4ce2-a534-c8101c39d847"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e6420bdb-b389-4ce2-a534-c8101c39d847" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mexico: Overview of the education system (EAG 2017) Database, indicator: attained a tertiary education degree, 25-64 year-olds (%), Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, September 6, 2018, gpseducation.oecd.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>To address this, CONACYT (Mexico’s National Council on Science and Technology) could fund a program dedicated to keeping primary and secondary school teachers up to date in STEM knowledge and providing them with new teaching methodologies. Government incentives that encourage students in rural areas to attend college could also be extremely helpful.</p>
<p>For existing workers, the Mexican government could consider spurring the development of reskilling programs that will prepare people who are going to be, or who already have been, displaced by the increasingly automated and service-oriented workplaces of the future. For example, through the SkillsFuture program, the government of Singapore collaborates with private companies to develop low-cost, massive, open, blended (in person and online) course programs to train new entrants to the workforce and reskill existing ones in new-economy skills, like data analytics and innovation.</p>
<h3>Creating smart regulation</h3>
<p>The development of new business models often creates a need for new or updated regulation. Mexico recently passed, and is in the process of implementing, a fintech law (Ley para Regular las Instituciones de Tecnología Financiera) that governs cryptocurrency transactions and establishes rules for connectivity via application programming interfaces. It also includes a regulatory “sandbox” in which companies without a banking license can test solutions with real customers.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Digitizing the state: Five tasks for national governments" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/digitizing%20the%20state%20five%20tasks%20for%20national%20governments/digitizing-the-state-five-tasks-for-nat-govt_1536x1536_100.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Digitizing the state: Five tasks for national governments</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/digitizing-the-state-five-tasks-for-national-governments" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Since regulation can be daunting for start-ups, structures that help explain rules, offer advice, provide forums for getting questions answered, and generally remove uncertainty for start-ups can go a long way toward fostering their creation. Singapore’s FinTech Office could be one such model. The government’s monetary authority and its National Research Foundation established a one-stop platform for financial start-ups, providing guidance, significantly reducing bureaucratic complexity, and, in effect, promoting Singapore as a fintech hub.</p>
<h3>Developing interoperability</h3>
<p>The traditional, siloed model of every agency procuring and maintaining its own technology is fading away. In its place are shared platforms and services that enable the seamless sharing and aggregation of data across agencies. With agencies powered by an integrated, cloud-based data architecture, citizens can go online to track the progress of complex, multiagency requests, use the same document to navigate multiple online processes, and get their identities verified in one simple step. This model also reduces paperwork, streamlines back-end processes, improves the government’s ability to provide targeted support programs, and allows real-time updates of databases. It also affords the kind of 360-degree view of citizens that enables governments to serve people more efficiently and effectively, a result much like what private-sector companies are trying to achieve.</p>
<p>Although Mexico has taken steps toward this kind of system compatibility, a systematic approach to enforcing standards is lacking. All federal agencies, for instance, are required to report standardized transparency data; yet the latest compliance report of the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Personal Data Protection focused on whether agencies filed their data on time, not on the quality of that data.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="61df1f91-7f3e-4b43-9805-a3c61bdbdafc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="61df1f91-7f3e-4b43-9805-a3c61bdbdafc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Acusan evaluación burocrática del INAI,” Nosotrxs, April 11, 2018, nosotrxs.org; InteroperaMX, gob.mx.</span></span></span></a></span> There is an effort to design norms for systems and data architecture as well as for shared back-office services, but at the time this article was published, the website for the government’s interoperability initiative featured several technical documents that were incomplete or entirely empty. Systematically enforcing technology standards and imposing penalties for noncompliance can go a long way toward ensuring a successful IT evolution.</p>
<h3>Addressing data privacy and cybersecurity</h3>
<p>Without proper security measures in place, people and systems are vulnerable to cyberattacks.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3597565c-c5fb-4da6-8c0a-431463243336"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3597565c-c5fb-4da6-8c0a-431463243336" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Abusaid, Andrea Cristofori, Rafael Fernández MacGregor, Sergio Waisser, <em>Perspectiva de ciberseguridad en México</em>, McKinsey and COMEXI, June 2018, consejomexicano.org.</span></span></span></a></span> In April 2018, vulnerability in the software that connects Mexican financial institutions to the Interbanking Electronic Payment System resulted in a theft of around $15 million and significant delays in electronic money transfers, including salary payments that were due during time of the attack.</p>
<p>Mexico has established several cybersecurity units (one of them within the Mexican Central Bank as a response to the attack<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d0d9d605-0bfc-41bf-955f-1fa19b386ed5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d0d9d605-0bfc-41bf-955f-1fa19b386ed5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Mexico central bank to create cyber security unit after hack,” Reuters, May 15, 2018, reuters.com.</span></span></span></a></span>) and defined the physical-, technical-, and administrative-security measures government agencies managing personal data must take. But the government might also consider playing aggressive defense so that it is ready for attacks. This can include hiring actual hackers to test the system and find vulnerabilities that need to be closed, and simulating attacks so that response plans can be implemented in real time. Each government agency could also have a risk profile established so that capabilities can be developed accordingly.</p>
<hr>
<p>Mexico has made substantial progress in digitizing its government in recent years. Yet before it can advance further and capture the significant economic potential of digital, the country may want to take a step back and fix some of its foundations, most notably internet access, which reflects the inequalities present in Mexican society. Mexico’s incoming administration could consider mapping out a clear path for how digital initiatives can help achieve its economic, educational, health-service, and national-security objectives.</p>
<p>No doubt, there will be significant challenges. Going digital will require an investment of financial resources, extensive coordination among the multiple stakeholders and levels of government, and new regulations governing the growing e-commerce and fintech sectors. It most likely would entail participation incentives for the private sector, since governments should not attempt to “go it alone.” In the end, both sectors of society stand to reap the value digitization will sow.</p>

Americas digital government powerhouse","displayName":"How Mexico can become Latin Americas digital government powerhouse","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"796ba622-3e05-47e3-b3b8-6908c3994ea4","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"How Mexico can become Latin America\u0026rsquo;s digital-government powerhouse"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Creating Mexico\u0026rsquo;s digital government"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Mexico\u0026rsquo;s digital efforts thus far have been laudable. But higher ambitions could fuel productivity and economic growth and boost the country\u0026rsquo;s GDP by 7 to 15 percent."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Mexico’s digital efforts thus far have been laudable. But higher ambitions could fuel productivity and economic growth for it to be a digital government powerhouse."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2018-11-01T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]] \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFor decades, Mexican citizens\u003c/strong\u003e who wanted to get a copy of their birth certificates underwent a long, tedious, and uncertain process. They needed to retrieve their parents\u0026rsquo; birth certificates, get a document signed by a representative of the Mexican Ministry of Health, and visit a local office of the Civil Registry. When the certificate finally arrived, anywhere between two weeks and two months later, there were sometimes errors in the name, date of birth, and even gender.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp left]]\n\u003cp\u003eToday, however, Mexicans can get a secure, certified, and error-free copy of their birth certificate\nwithin minutes by logging onto gob.mx, a one-stop portal that consolidates 34,000 databases from 250 government institutions and 5,400 public services.[[footnote 1]] The site, launched in 2014, is the centerpiece of Mexico\u0026rsquo;s drive to digitize the operations of its federal government\u0026mdash;part of a wave of such efforts \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-opportunity-in-government-productivity\"\u003eto improve government productivity\u003c/a\u003e taking place across the globe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStill in the early stages of its digitization journey, Mexico ranks 55th in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s analysis of the digital maturity of 151 countries.[[footnote 2]] When compared with countries with similar per capita GDPs, this is a laudable standing. But Mexico has yet to achieve the kind of world-class digital transformation that fuels productivity and economic growth; as of right now, the country is about halfway there. To move forward, the Mexican government\u0026rsquo;s ambitions should be more closely aligned with those of \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/digitizing-the-state-five-tasks-for-national-governments\"\u003ehigher-performing countries\u003c/a\u003e like Estonia and Malaysia\u0026mdash;nations with income levels close to that of Mexico but that \u0026ldquo;punch above their weight\u0026rdquo; in regard to digital maturity (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe estimate that were Mexico to attain a \u0026ldquo;good\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;very good\u0026rdquo; digital-maturity rating, it would boost\nthe country\u0026rsquo;s GDP by 7 to 15 percent (or $115 billion to $240 billion) by 2025. The growth would come from greater productivity and employment in existing sectors, the creation of new digital (or digitally powered) businesses, the expansion of the information-and-communication-technology (ICT) sector, and a successful labor-force transition to these new digital industries (Exhibit 2).[[footnote 3]] As the second-largest economy in Latin America, Mexico also has a unique opportunity to set the standards for what a digitally enabled government looks like in the region.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n[[sidebar underspending]]\n\u003cp\u003eImplementing these kind of changes is no small task (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Mexico\u0026rsquo;s digital underspending\u0026rdquo;). First, Mexico needs to invest significant additional resources in ICTs, since its government spending lags behind in relation to the weighted average for our benchmark countries: 1.5 percent of the federal budget goes toward ICT versus the 3.9 percent weighted average.[[footnote 4]] To get up to speed, we estimate that public and private spending on ICT in Mexico would need to increase by at least 5 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow Mexico stacks up\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we look at how Mexico is faring along the four critical dimensions used to define digital maturity (government, foundations, economy, and society) (Exhibit 3) and outline the next steps the government could consider taking to become a leader in the digital future.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eDigital foundations\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor citizens to participate in the services of a digital state, they must first have access to the internet, mobile networks, and other secure data infrastructure. But in 2016, Mexico had just 13 fixed-line broadband subscriptions for every 100 inhabitants, ranking it last among both Latin American and Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) peers.[[footnote 5]] The rate of subscription to mobile broadband is higher, at 61 percent,[[footnote 6]] but this still leaves a sizable portion of the population unconnected and thus spending additional time and money getting to physical centers to access government services. Because of this, Mexico ranks 93rd (again, last among all OECD countries) in our digital-foundations dimension.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDigital government\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMexico has made notable progress in its efforts to offer web and mobile access to public services (for those with such access) and to make government more efficient by automating internal processes. In addition to the gob.mx portal, the country has created the role of national digital strategy coordinator within the president\u0026rsquo;s office and has established a national digital strategy. This has resulted in successful initiatives to make government data available to anyone and has made Mexico the leading Latin American country on the Open Data Barometer world ranking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe country, however, receives low scores from its citizens on their overall satisfaction with the convenience and accessibility of government services. In a recent survey, Mexico had the worst-rated citizen experience (4.4 out of 10) of the group of countries surveyed (Canada, France, Germany, Mexico, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and the largest perception gap between what people experience in the private sector versus the public sector.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn our digital-government subanalysis, Mexico comes in at 39th (out of 151 countries), similar to Chile, Ireland, and Israel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDigital economy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMexico\u0026rsquo;s shaky digital foundations hurt its ability to have mature digital ICT industries. In addition to diminished access to high-speed internet, the reliability of postal services is low, and fewer than\n40 percent of Mexicans over the age of 15 have a bank account.[[footnote 8]] As a result, the country is estimated to have poor potential for developing a robust e-commerce sector, which requires efficient delivery of products and digital forms of payment.[[footnote 9]] Moreover, less than 1 percent of Mexico\u0026rsquo;s exported goods and services relate to ICT. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s digital-economy subindex places Mexico in 92nd place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDigital society\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDigitization can improve the quality of life for citizens by fostering greater civic participation, providing access to information, and offering new tools for health and education. In recent years, Mexico has accelerated its digital-society efforts and ranks 34th on McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s index. On gob.mx/participa, for instance, citizens participate in public polls and discuss government policies on forums and blogs. At datos.gob.mx/retos, which provides access to Retos P\u0026uacute;blicos (retos is Spanish for challenges), software entrepreneurs can present solutions to complex public-policy problems, such as the creation of earthquake alerts through push notifications on mobile phones.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eUnlocking the opportunity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo attain the meaningful economic and societal benefits that come from having a digital government, there are three basic initiatives Mexican government leaders could consider putting on top of their priority lists.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDefining a digital vision and strategy, then linking them to policy priorities\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAny successful digital transformation\u0026mdash;whether in the private or public sector\u0026mdash;depends on having a clear vision and defined goals, and then setting priorities. For governments, this means intimately linking digital to public-policy objectives and viewing it as a lever for achieving them. In India, for example, the government framed its goal of transforming the country into a digitally empowered society and knowledge economy in this way: \u0026ldquo;digital infrastructure as a utility to every citizen.\u0026rdquo; The UK government talks about developing a world-leading digital economy that works for everyone. To establish a clear link between its digital vision and public value, Mexico\u0026rsquo;s incoming administration may want to consider revisiting the country\u0026rsquo;s 2013 National Digital Strategy and aligning it with Mexico\u0026rsquo;s current and future needs, as well as with the new government\u0026rsquo;s priorities.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis digital vision should be accompanied by a clear set of milestones and metrics that monitor its implementation and impact closely. To ensure success, initiatives that don\u0026rsquo;t yield the expected results should be rigorously evaluated and adjusted or deprioritized in relation to resources. Such a \u0026ldquo;test and learn\u0026rdquo; practice is not native to the public sector and will require the use of different budgeting practices, such as top-down budgets that allow a certain amount of flexibility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSetting up the correct delivery mechanism\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDigital transformations require ways of working that are very different from how governments normally operate. Instead of remaking products, processes, and policies according to what benefits each agency, governments running successful transformations typically orient their efforts around what citizens desire and expect. This requires unprecedented, and at times uncomfortable, levels of coordination among previously siloed entities, such as different government agencies, levels of government, and private-sector stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo accelerate and streamline this transformation, Mexico could double down on its efforts to centralize digital initiatives across government agencies by providing shared platforms and services so that individual units do not need to \u0026ldquo;reinvent the wheel\u0026rdquo; and can focus on actual service delivery. Initially, this could involve coordination through a high-level council that meets regularly. Such a council would oversee digital transformation across the government, including deciding a rollout schedule of initiatives and monitoring their progress with a publicly scrutinized set of periodic key performance indicators. It would also identify obstacles and give support to the different government agencies that can address them. If issues cannot be resolved at this level, the council should have the capacity to escalate them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIdeally, this central group would have a direct role in designing interoperability and data-architecture standards and would perform ongoing reviews of the digital solutions being implemented by different government agencies. It would also ensure there is a consistent user experience (front end) and compatibility with the data and systems of other agencies (back end). Likewise, the group could play a limited role in implementing pilots or new strategic initiatives, either through its own \u0026ldquo;digital factory\u0026rdquo;[[footnote 10]] or by managing external vendors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEventually, and in a more advanced scenario, the government could form a separate digital delivery unit. The government of Singapore, for example, established the Government Technology Agency (GovTech) as an implementing agency for the Smart Nation and Digital Government Office, both part of the Smart Nation and Digital Government Group under the Prime Minister\u0026rsquo;s Office.[[footnote 11]] The unit usually has a strong sponsor. As in Singapore, it may report to the president or prime minister, or the president or prime minister serves as the chair of periodic progress-review meetings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eBuilding digital foundations\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause the gaps in Mexico\u0026rsquo;s digital foundations have ramifications for each of the three other dimensions, we suggest that addressing five essential building blocks could shore up the country\u0026rsquo;s infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBoosting digital accessibility\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo increase internet access across Mexico, both national and state-level governments could provide private companies with specific incentives for investing in broadband networks in marginalized communities, such as Chiapas and Oaxaca.[[footnote 12]] In India, for example, the central government helped develop the National Optical Fibre Network (BharatNet) through tax incentives to private providers that make investments in infrastructure. This effort successfully brought broadband services to approximately 115,000 villages, aiming to deliver broadband connectivity to 250,000 villages overall.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eNurturing the right kind of talent\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy 2030, automation technologies are expected to displace nine million workers in Mexico,[[footnote 14]] with the eventual replacement jobs requiring entirely different skills and competencies\u0026mdash;most of which the current Mexican educational system is not fully prepared to address. In recent years, Mexico has made significant strides to boost the number of college graduates with degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). In 2016, 25 percent of graduates were from STEM disciplines, which is equal to the OECD average. But overall, Mexico\u0026rsquo;s education system still lags behind. According to a World Economic Forum survey, the quality of Mexico\u0026rsquo;s mathematics and science education ranks 126th out of 139 countries.[[footnote 15]] And only 17 percent of Mexicans graduate from college (as compared with the OECD average of 37 percent), making the overall talent pool small.[[footnote 16]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address this, CONACYT (Mexico\u0026rsquo;s National Council on Science and Technology) could fund a program dedicated to keeping primary and secondary school teachers up to date in STEM knowledge and providing them with new teaching methodologies. Government incentives that encourage students in rural areas to attend college could also be extremely helpful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor existing workers, the Mexican government could consider spurring the development of reskilling programs that will prepare people who are going to be, or who already have been, displaced by the increasingly automated and service-oriented workplaces of the future. For example, through the SkillsFuture program, the government of Singapore collaborates with private companies to develop low-cost, massive, open, blended (in person and online) course programs to train new entrants to the workforce and reskill existing ones in new-economy skills, like data analytics and innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCreating smart regulation\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe development of new business models often creates a need for new or updated regulation. Mexico recently passed, and is in the process of implementing, a fintech law (Ley para Regular las Instituciones de Tecnolog\u0026iacute;a Financiera) that governs cryptocurrency transactions and establishes rules for connectivity via application programming interfaces. It also includes a regulatory \u0026ldquo;sandbox\u0026rdquo; in which companies without a banking license can test solutions with real customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eSince regulation can be daunting for start-ups, structures that help explain rules, offer advice, provide forums for getting questions answered, and generally remove uncertainty for start-ups can go a long way toward fostering their creation. Singapore\u0026rsquo;s FinTech Office could be one such model. The government\u0026rsquo;s monetary authority and its National Research Foundation established a one-stop platform for financial start-ups, providing guidance, significantly reducing bureaucratic complexity, and, in effect, promoting Singapore as a fintech hub.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDeveloping interoperability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe traditional, siloed model of every agency procuring and maintaining its own technology is fading away. In its place are shared platforms and services that enable the seamless sharing and aggregation of data across agencies. With agencies powered by an integrated, cloud-based data architecture, citizens can go online to track the progress of complex, multiagency requests, use the same document to navigate multiple online processes, and get their identities verified in one simple step. This model also reduces paperwork, streamlines back-end processes, improves the government\u0026rsquo;s ability to provide targeted support programs, and allows real-time updates of databases. It also affords the kind of 360-degree view of citizens that enables governments to serve people more efficiently and effectively, a result much like what private-sector companies are trying to achieve.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough Mexico has taken steps toward this kind of system compatibility, a systematic approach to enforcing standards is lacking. All federal agencies, for instance, are required to report standardized transparency data; yet the latest compliance report of the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Personal Data Protection focused on whether agencies filed their data on time, not on the quality of that data.[[footnote 17]] There is an effort to design norms for systems and data architecture as well as for shared back-office services, but at the time this article was published, the website for the government\u0026rsquo;s interoperability initiative featured several technical documents that were incomplete or entirely empty. Systematically enforcing technology standards and imposing penalties for noncompliance can go a long way toward ensuring a successful IT evolution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAddressing data privacy and cybersecurity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWithout proper security measures in place, people and systems are vulnerable to cyberattacks.[[footnote 18]] In April 2018, vulnerability in the software that connects Mexican financial institutions to the Interbanking Electronic Payment System resulted in a theft of around $15 million and significant delays in electronic money transfers, including salary payments that were due during time of the attack.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMexico has established several cybersecurity units (one of them within the Mexican Central Bank as a response to the attack[[footnote 19]]) and defined the physical-, technical-, and administrative-security measures government agencies managing personal data must take. But the government might also consider playing aggressive defense so that it is ready for attacks. This can include hiring actual hackers to test the system and find vulnerabilities that need to be closed, and simulating attacks so that response plans can be implemented in real time. Each government agency could also have a risk profile established so that capabilities can be developed accordingly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMexico has made substantial progress in digitizing its government in recent years. Yet before it can advance further and capture the significant economic potential of digital, the country may want to take a step back and fix some of its foundations, most notably internet access, which reflects the inequalities present in Mexican society. Mexico\u0026rsquo;s incoming administration could consider mapping out a clear path for how digital initiatives can help achieve its economic, educational, health-service, and national-security objectives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo doubt, there will be significant challenges. Going digital will require an investment of financial resources, extensive coordination among the multiple stakeholders and levels of government, and new regulations governing the growing e-commerce and fintech sectors. It most likely would entail participation incentives for the private sector, since governments should not attempt to \u0026ldquo;go it alone.\u0026rdquo; In the end, both sectors of society stand to reap the value digitization will sow.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp
